speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: SCENE III. LEONATO'S orchard.

speaker: DON JOHN
text_entry: Enter BENEDICK

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Boy!

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Enter Boy

speaker: Boy
text_entry: Signior?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: In my chamber-window lies a book: bring it hither

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: to me in the orchard.

speaker: Boy
text_entry: I am here already, sir.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I know that; but I would have thee hence, and here again.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Exit Boy

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I do much wonder that one man, seeing how much

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: another man is a fool when he dedicates his

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: behaviors to love, will, after he hath laughed at

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: such shallow follies in others, become the argument

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: of his own scorn by failing in love: and such a man

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: is Claudio. I have known when there was no music

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: with him but the drum and the fife; and now had he

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: rather hear the tabour and the pipe: I have known

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: when he would have walked ten mile a-foot to see a

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: good armour; and now will he lie ten nights awake,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: carving the fashion of a new doublet. He was wont to

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: speak plain and to the purpose, like an honest man

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: and a soldier; and now is he turned orthography; his

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: words are a very fantastical banquet, just so many

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: strange dishes. May I be so converted and see with

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: these eyes? I cannot tell; I think not: I will not

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: be sworn, but love may transform me to an oyster; but

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I'll take my oath on it, till he have made an oyster

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: of me, he shall never make me such a fool. One woman

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: is fair, yet I am well; another is wise, yet I am

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: well; another virtuous, yet I am well; but till all

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: graces be in one woman, one woman shall not come in

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: my grace. Rich she shall be, that's certain; wise,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: or I'll none; virtuous, or I'll never cheapen her;

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: fair, or I'll   never look on her; mild, or come not

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: near me; noble, or not I for an angel; of good

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: discourse, an excellent musician, and her hair shall

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: be of what colour it please God. Ha! the prince and

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Monsieur Love! I will hide me in the arbour.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Withdraws

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, and LEONATO

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Come, shall we hear this music?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Yea, my good lord. How still the evening is,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: As hush'd on purpose to grace harmony!

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: See you where Benedick hath hid himself?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: O, very well, my lord: the music ended,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: We'll fit the kid-fox with a pennyworth.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Enter BALTHASAR with Music

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Come, Balthasar, we'll hear that song again.

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: O, good my lord, tax not so bad a voice

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: To slander music any more than once.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: It is the witness still of excellency

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: To put a strange face on his own perfection.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: I pray thee, sing, and let me woo no more.

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Because you talk of wooing, I will sing;

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Since many a wooer doth commence his suit

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: To her he thinks not worthy, yet he wooes,

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Yet will he swear he loves.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Now, pray thee, come;

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Or, if thou wilt hold longer argument,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Do it in notes.

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Note this before my notes;

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: There's not a note of mine that's worth the noting.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Why, these are very crotchets that he speaks;

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Note, notes, forsooth, and nothing.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Air

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Now, divine air! now is his soul ravished! Is it

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: not strange that sheeps' guts should hale souls out

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: of men's bodies? Well, a horn for my money, when

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: all's done.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: The Song

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Sigh no more, ladies, sigh no more,

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Men were deceivers ever,

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: One foot in sea and one on shore,

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: To one thing constant never:

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Then sigh not so, but let them go,

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: And be you blithe and bonny,

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Converting all your sounds of woe

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Into Hey nonny, nonny.

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Sing no more ditties, sing no moe,

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Of dumps so dull and heavy;

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: The fraud of men was ever so,

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Since summer first was leafy:

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: Then sigh not so,  and c.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: By my troth, a good song.

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: And an ill singer, my lord.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Ha, no, no, faith; thou singest well enough for a shift.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: An he had been a dog that should have howled thus,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: they would have hanged him: and I pray God his bad

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: voice bode no mischief. I had as lief have heard the

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: night-raven, come what plague could have come after

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: it.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Yea, marry, dost thou hear, Balthasar? I pray thee,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: get us some excellent music; for to-morrow night we

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: would have it at the Lady Hero's chamber-window.

speaker: BALTHASAR
text_entry: The best I can, my lord.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Do so: farewell.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Exit BALTHASAR

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Come hither, Leonato. What was it you told me of

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: to-day, that your niece Beatrice was in love with

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Signior Benedick?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: O, ay: stalk on. stalk on; the fowl sits. I did

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: never think that lady would have loved any man.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: No, nor I neither; but most wonderful that she

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: should so dote on Signior Benedick, whom she hath in

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: all outward behaviors seemed ever to abhor.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Is't possible? Sits the wind in that corner?

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: By my troth, my lord, I cannot tell what to think

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: of it but that she loves him with an enraged

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: affection: it is past the infinite of thought.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: May be she doth but counterfeit.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Faith, like enough.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: O God, counterfeit! There was never counterfeit of

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: passion came so near the life of passion as she

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: discovers it.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Why, what effects of passion shows she?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Bait the hook well; this fish will bite.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: What effects, my lord? She will sit you, you heard

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: my daughter tell you how.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: She did, indeed.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: How, how, pray you? You amaze me: I would have I

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: thought her spirit had been invincible against all

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: assaults of affection.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: I would have sworn it had, my lord; especially

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: against Benedick.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: I should think this a gull, but that the

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: white-bearded fellow speaks it: knavery cannot,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: sure, hide himself in such reverence.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: He hath ta'en the infection: hold it up.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Hath she made her affection known to Benedick?

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: No; and swears she never will: that's her torment.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: 'Tis true, indeed; so your daughter says: 'Shall

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: I,' says she, 'that have so oft encountered him

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: with scorn, write to him that I love him?'

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: This says she now when she is beginning to write to

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: him; for she'll be up twenty times a night, and

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: there will she sit in her smock till she have writ a

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: sheet of paper: my daughter tells us all.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Now you talk of a sheet of paper, I remember a

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: pretty jest your daughter told us of.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: O, when she had writ it and was reading it over, she

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: found Benedick and Beatrice between the sheet?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: That.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: O, she tore the letter into a thousand halfpence;

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: railed at herself, that she should be so immodest

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: to write to one that she knew would flout her; 'I

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: measure him,' says she, 'by my own spirit; for I

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: should flout him, if he writ to me; yea, though I

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: love him, I should.'

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Then down upon her knees she falls, weeps, sobs,

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: beats her heart, tears her hair, prays, curses; 'O

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: sweet Benedick! God give me patience!'

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: She doth indeed; my daughter says so: and the

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: ecstasy hath so much overborne her that my daughter

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: is sometime afeared she will do a desperate outrage

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: to herself: it is very true.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: It were good that Benedick knew of it by some

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: other, if she will not discover it.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: To what end? He would make but a sport of it and

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: torment the poor lady worse.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: An he should, it were an alms to hang him. She's an

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: excellent sweet lady; and, out of all suspicion,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: she is virtuous.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: And she is exceeding wise.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: In every thing but in loving Benedick.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: O, my lord, wisdom and blood combating in so tender

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: a body, we have ten proofs to one that blood hath

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: the victory. I am sorry for her, as I have just

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: cause, being her uncle and her guardian.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: I would she had bestowed this dotage on me: I would

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: have daffed all other respects and made her half

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: myself. I pray you, tell Benedick of it, and hear

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: what a' will say.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Were it good, think you?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Hero thinks surely she will die; for she says she

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: will die, if he love her not, and she will die, ere

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: she make her love known, and she will die, if he woo

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: her, rather than she will bate one breath of her

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: accustomed crossness.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: She doth well: if she should make tender of her

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: love, 'tis very possible he'll scorn it; for the

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: man, as you know all, hath a contemptible spirit.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: He is a very proper man.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: He hath indeed a good outward happiness.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Before God! and, in my mind, very wise.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: He doth indeed show some sparks that are like wit.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: And I take him to be valiant.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: As Hector, I assure you: and in the managing of

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: quarrels you may say he is wise; for either he

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: avoids them with great discretion, or undertakes

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: them with a most Christian-like fear.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: If he do fear God, a' must necessarily keep peace:

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: if he break the peace, he ought to enter into a

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: quarrel with fear and trembling.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: And so will he do; for the man doth fear God,

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: howsoever it seems not in him by some large jests

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: he will make. Well I am sorry for your niece. Shall

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: we go seek Benedick, and tell him of her love?

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: Never tell him, my lord: let her wear it out with

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: good counsel.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: Nay, that's impossible: she may wear her heart out first.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Well, we will hear further of it by your daughter:

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: let it cool the while. I love Benedick well; and I

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: could wish he would modestly examine himself, to see

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: how much he is unworthy so good a lady.

speaker: LEONATO
text_entry: My lord, will you walk? dinner is ready.

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: If he do not dote on her upon this, I will never

speaker: CLAUDIO
text_entry: trust my expectation.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Let there be the same net spread for her; and that

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: must your daughter and her gentlewomen carry. The

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: sport will be, when they hold one an opinion of

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: another's dotage, and no such matter: that's the

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: scene that I would see, which will be merely a

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: dumb-show. Let us send her to call him in to dinner.

speaker: DON PEDRO
text_entry: Exeunt DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, and LEONATO

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: [Coming forward]  This can be no trick: the

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: conference was sadly borne. They have the truth of

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: this from Hero. They seem to pity the lady: it

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: seems her affections have their full bent. Love me!

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: why, it must be requited. I hear how I am censured:

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: they say I will bear myself proudly, if I perceive

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: the love come from her; they say too that she will

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: rather die than give any sign of affection. I did

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: never think to marry: I must not seem proud: happy

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: are they that hear their detractions and can put

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: them to mending. They say the lady is fair; 'tis a

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: truth, I can bear them witness; and virtuous; 'tis

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: so, I cannot reprove it; and wise, but for loving

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: me; by my troth, it is no addition to her wit, nor

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: no great argument of her folly, for I will be

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: horribly in love with her. I may chance have some

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: odd quirks and remnants of wit broken on me,

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: because I have railed so long against marriage: but

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: doth not the appetite alter? a man loves the meat

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: in his youth that he cannot endure in his age.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Shall quips and sentences and these paper bullets of

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: the brain awe a man from the career of his humour?

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: No, the world must be peopled. When I said I would

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: die a bachelor, I did not think I should live till I

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: were married. Here comes Beatrice. By this day!

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: she's a fair lady: I do spy some marks of love in

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: her.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Enter BEATRICE

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Against my will I am sent to bid you come in to dinner.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Fair Beatrice, I thank you for your pains.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: I took no more pains for those thanks than you take

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: pains to thank me: if it had been painful, I would

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: not have come.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: You take pleasure then in the message?

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Yea, just so much as you may take upon a knife's

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: point and choke a daw withal. You have no stomach,

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: signior: fare you well.

speaker: BEATRICE
text_entry: Exit

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Ha! 'Against my will I am sent to bid you come in

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: to dinner;' there's a double meaning in that 'I took

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: no more pains for those thanks than you took pains

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: to thank me.' that's as much as to say, Any pains

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: that I take for you is as easy as thanks. If I do

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: not take pity of her, I am a villain; if I do not

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: love her, I am a Jew. I will go get her picture.

speaker: BENEDICK
text_entry: Exit
